name: Quick Upgrades
description:
Who wants a free Biotic Labor for the rest of the game? Me too.

Your immediate goal with this deck should be scoring out an agenda as quickly as possible. Scoring Upgrades first is ideal, but any of the others is fine too. If it's Vitruvius, try to over-advance at least once: you'll want a Biotic Labor or Shipment from Sansan back later. All the pressure is on the runner after you've scored just 1 agenda. Just keep padding your bank account and ICEing up R&D, since that is where they'll beat you. Otherwise, score out whatever agendas you draw. Use Efficiency Committee tokens, Shipments, Biotic Labors and SanSans, and then use Reclamation Order or your Jacksons to get the cards you need back. As a sidenote: I've actually never rezzed a SanSan City Grid so far in testing. They've only really served as a tax for the runner, and I'm perfectly fine with that.

name: Noise "V" (Melbourne Regionals 2014 winner)
description:
Simply an updated version of this:

http://netrunnerdb.com/en/decklist/3267/noise-v-goodgames-melbourne-store-championship-winner-

I won't repeat the things I've said before but recently I have realised that there are three phases to my game plan.

Phase 1: Aggression and luck

The first few clicks of the game involves installing datasucker(s), face checking ice and running archives when it is unprotected - a lot of the time purely to build up sucker tokens - but also about 20% of the time you will see an agenda from the mill - that's the luck element.

If the corp takes a mulligan, I give serious thought to mulliganing hard for a Medium. A lot of games are won from Medium digging an unprotected R&D from turn 1.

The plan is to keep the corp poor from rezzing ice and to put the pressure on right from the start if you get early points.

My favourite starting play is: Sure Gamble, install Datasucker, run R&D, Dirty Laundry archives.

Phase 2: Control

I think many people don't realise that the middle game for Noise is actually a control game. Crypsis + counters + A LOT of money is very threatening and this would be what I consider the optimum middle game state. Wherever the corp is not defending well - attack there. Once they start dedicating resources and time to making a big remote and advancing agendas - I probably won't be able to get in and that is the truth - but that is also the best time to attack R&D or HQ. So really, it's all about diverting attention from where you're really planning to make a big run.

Phase 3: Go hard or go home

The late game (if you haven't won by now) will typically have very well defended servers and a corp beginning to turn the economy tide in their favour. As soon as they are on 5 points and threatening to score for the win, that is when I will start keeping tags, mass installing viruses and stimhacking servers like a mad man. Sometimes it's stimhacking a remote for the agenda, sometimes it's stimhacking for one last Medium dig, sometimes its installing multiple viruses then hitting archives. The most important thing to be able to do is to work out which server is most agenda-dense. That is the number one skill to have when playing Noise. This is Netrunner at its most fun and the most you will feel like you are truly playing as an Anarch.

And one more thing - for Noise, the game is not in archives. The game is in HQ. Corps tend to try really hard to defend their archives and R&D. They often leave their HQ poorly protected because they are not expecting me to run there. Agendas tend to accumulate in HQ because they are too afraid to try to advance them in remotes with Crypsis out. I win 50% of my games from single access HQ runs. Once Legwork came out - I had to put a copy of it in my deck.

Also, realise that if you are not milling agendas then the only place for them to go is HQ and all their ice and economy has just been milled into archives, making it even harder to defend their agendas in HQ.

name: NBN "Morag" (Melbourne Regionals 2014 winner)
description:
Simply an updated version of this:

http://netrunnerdb.com/en/decklist/3268/nbn-morag-goodgames-melbourne-store-championship-winner-

Fast Track means that the deck is now using Psychographics as the primary fast advance method with SanSan City Grid playing a smaller role.

Eli, Viper and Draco remain kings.

name: Noise Blasting Shop
description: Simple put together of my Noise deck, changed some things after testing it though. Still getting used to building properly, so we'll see how this goes.

name: Shape of a Criminal v5.0
description: Lots of thanks to ImTheBanker for making me realize that I don't necessarily need Diesel to "speed" my progress along, heh. Recursion, good drip econ, and extra anti-Corp econ can also "do a body good"! Done a bit of streamlining as well to my original deck idea, so here it is! Feedback welcome. :)

name: I don't understand Haas-Bioroid yet...
description: ...so here's what i'm planning to start learning with :-)

name: Unforeseen delays
description:
A deck based on breaking the econ of the corp while optimising your own econ and draws.

This version is very pure build of the concept as there is no way to prevent any form of damage or destroying of all those precious resources.

name: We Three.
description:
I wanted to build a deck with Bernice, Midori and Simone in that could make use of these three sysop powers.

So it's hopefully got some easy rez ice that Midori can drop in, ice for advancing, trick of light to move it around, and some scorched earths to do something with the tags.

The ladies have a Dedicated Response Team, an Encryption Protocol and a Snare in case they need these things.

Deck is probably totally lacking in focus as a result of trying to go in too many different directions, but it has some possibilities that entertain me.

Any ideas on how to build a deck where the only rule is that you must have one card each of these three sysops? :-)

name: All Over the World
description:
One side is hot the other side is not.

I don't know about this one. I quite like the idea of using NBN with a lot of regions and employing psychic staff and portals to facilitate repeat viewings of your pop-up windows.

Like most of the decks that i'm looking at it seems to be built on the idea of doing lots of things and diluting itself... ah well.

name: Flat Broke
description:
Ideas simple keep the corp poor.

Derz their ICE, Forge unrezed ice when they have no cash and generally annoy them.

I am not entirely sure it will work with their been no recurrence what so ever but its still in testing stages.

name: Tipical Mill w/Donut
description: Drop 2x Hemo for 2x Lamprey as soon as Upstalk is available :)

name: Big Girls Play With Monoliths v2.4
OverChaos
description: As a first deck, I'm trying to do something with Chaos Theory and Overmind. But I'm not sure I'm doing things right...
